awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Ocean Science & Engineering at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution 2022-2024 Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI), located in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, will host a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site for ten undergraduates each year who will participate in the Summer Student Fellows (SSF) program. WHOI is one of the largest independent oceanographic institutions and research fleet operators in the world, and SSFs are offered a wide range of research opportunities. Students are recruited nationally from all major science and engineering disciplines, usually during their Junior year in college. Each Fellow is matched with an advisor(s) and is encouraged to discuss potential projects with them. Fellows and advisors together complete a work plan early on, then during the summer, each SSF conducts independent research and makes two presentations: a five-minute mid- summer oral progress report, and a final oral or poster presentation on their research. A written final project report is required. Professional development activities include a special lecture series, a one-day field experience on the R/V Tioga, a Responsible Conduct of Research workshop, training on how to prepare a scientific poster, and discussions about graduate school with a postdoc/graduate student panel. SSFs often present their results at professional conferences after the program is over and/or co-author publications in peer-reviewed journals.

WHOI’s REU program is aimed at students interested in exploring the full range of sub-disciplines within oceanography. This includes biological, chemical, geological, and physical oceanography, plus ocean engineering and marine policy, with several of these disciplines requiring strong foundations in math and physics. For example, the program offers opportunities for physics, engineering, and math majors to explore application of their undergraduate major to areas of study that they may not have yet envisioned, such as ocean circulation, robotics, and climate modeling. Summer Student Fellows (SSFs) also have access to state-of-the-art analytical instruments, sampling devices and modeling programs for their research projects in a wide range of disciplines; themes that crosscut disciplines include oceans and climate, the Arctic, autonomous underwater vehicles and systems, and human-ocean interactions and impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since 1959, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) has run a Summer Student Fellow (SSF) Program for STEM undergraduates. Today, the program offers a 12 week residential experience in which the students engage in a hands-on research project, supervised by WHOI faculty. Additional educational and career development activities are organized, including a lecture series tailored to a broad undergraduate audience, an ethics in science workshop, and a day trip on the WHOI research vessel Tioga.

In each year of the program, 10 students are supported by NSF as part of a larger cohort (typically 28-30 students) with the additional students supported by private funding. Admission to the program is highly competitive through a holistic review process, with somewhere between 6-17% of applicants being offered a position.

Summer Student Fellows use state-of-the-art analytical instruments, sampling devices and modeling programs for their research projects in a wide range of oceans-science and engineering disciplines, including in marine policy. Some projects span multiple disciplines. The projects carried out by WHOI SSFs span a wide range of topics, and example research areas include: oceans and climate; the changing Arctic; deep-sea exploration and robotics; ocean observing systems; biogeochemical processes and cycles; seafloor processes and evolution; and human-ocean interactions and impacts. Fellows are encouraged to present their research at a scientific meeting, and WHOI pays the travel expenses for at least ten students each year. Many students are authors or co-authors on peer-reviewed papers stemming from their summer research project.

The primary aim of the program is to expose STEM undergraduates to ocean sciences, a subject that is not widely taught in undergraduate programs. This exposure allows students to see career paths that might not have been apparent to them. Entraining students from basic science and engineering backgrounds into ocean fields helps develop a workforce that is important for the Blue Economy, national security and basic research in this arena. Fellows are provided a number of professional development opportunities aimed at helping them understand their full range of graduate school and career options. Tracking of SSFs since 2011 shows over 80% go on to science graduate programs or work in a STEM field. Of the 2022/2023 cohort, 9 are pursuing PhDs, 2 are enrolled in Master’s programs, and 6 are employed as engineers or technicians. The 2024 cohort are currently finishing their bachelor’s degree programs.
